intro: Scirpus baeothryon var. major, commonly known as the tall bulrush, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland environments in North America. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, commonly referred to as the sedge family. This variant is characterized by its tall, cylindrical stems that can reach heights of up to 2 meters, often growing in dense clusters. Its leaves are narrow and grass-like, and it produces small, spike-like inflorescences that contain numerous tiny flowers. The plant plays an important ecological role in wetland ecosystems by stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various aquatic organisms.
